articles.headline: Some Purchases May Still Be Worth the Price
articles.snippet: It is now harder to take out our wallets without feeling guilty, but it’s easy to forget several important things.
articles.abstract: It is now harder to take out our wallets without feeling guilty, but it’s easy to forget several important things.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the last month or so, it has become much harder to take out our wallets without feeling guilty.

articles.headline: On Reality TV, Even ‘Survivor’ Looks Mortal
articles.snippet: Competition-based reality programs are showing their age, but are a proven way to keep costs down in a precarious economy.
articles.abstract: Competition-based reality programs are showing their age, but are a proven way to keep costs down in a precarious economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Los Angeles

articles.headline: Shouldn’t We Rescue Housing?
articles.snippet: Now that the government has “saved” Wall Street, it needs to tackle the continuing decline of housing prices.
articles.abstract: Now that the government has “saved” Wall Street, it needs to tackle the continuing decline of housing prices.
articles.lead_paragraph: Now that the government has “saved” Wall Street  at least for the moment  hasn’t the time finally come to save Main Street too?

articles.headline: Behind McCain, Outsider in Capital Wanting Back In
articles.snippet: Cindy McCain is pursuing a return to Washington, “a harsh town” that she has said does not suit her.
articles.abstract: Cindy McCain is pursuing a return to Washington, “a harsh town” that she has said does not suit her.
articles.lead_paragraph: Cindy McCain was new to Washington and not yet 30 when she arrived at a luncheon for Congressional spouses to discover a problem with her name tag.
articles.byline: By Jodi Kantor and David M. Halbfinger

articles.headline: Financial Crisis Provides Fertile Ground for Boom in Lawsuits
articles.snippet: Accusations of executive excess, accounting fraud and lack of disclosure are becoming far more credible now.
articles.abstract: Accusations of executive excess, accounting fraud and lack of disclosure are becoming far more credible now.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nothing makes lawyers more popular than bad times.

articles.headline: The Guys From ‘Government Sachs’
articles.snippet: Alumni of the Treasury chief’s old firm, Goldman Sachs, are key to the federal response to the financial crisis.
articles.abstract: Alumni of the Treasury chief’s old firm, Goldman Sachs, are key to the federal response to the financial crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: THIS summer, when the Treasury secretary, Henry M. Paulson Jr., sought help navigating the Wall Street meltdown, he turned to his old firm, Goldman Sachs, snagging a handful of former bankers and other experts in corporate restructurings.
articles.byline: By Julie Creswell and Ben White

articles.headline: Empires Built on Debt Start to Crumble
articles.snippet: In the current global financial crisis, tycoons with Kremlin ties are shouldering a heavy burden as Russian markets fall.
articles.abstract: In the current global financial crisis, tycoons with Kremlin ties are shouldering a heavy burden as Russian markets fall.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Are the Russian oligarchs going bust?

articles.headline: We’ll Rescue You on Four Conditions
articles.snippet: It is only fitting that restrictions on executive pay be part of any deal in which taxpayers rescue companies that helped drive the country into a ditch.
articles.abstract: It is only fitting that restrictions on executive pay be part of any deal in which taxpayers rescue companies that helped drive the country into a ditch.
articles.lead_paragraph: YOU may have been wondering what it takes to get overpaid executives to rein in excessive compensation. Well, now you know. It takes a historic financial market conflagration and hundreds of billions of taxpayer dollars in bailouts.

articles.headline: Government’s Leap Into Banking Has Its Perils
articles.snippet: Some earlier government interventions funneled money to political favorites instead of an economy’s innovators.
articles.abstract: Some earlier government interventions funneled money to political favorites instead of an economy’s innovators.
articles.lead_paragraph: Now that the big five investment banks of America have been shut down, sold off or turned into more staid bank holding companies, there is one big risk-taking banker left: the federal government.

articles.headline: Nearing Record, Obama’s Ad Effort Swamps McCain
articles.snippet: Barack Obama is using an advertising campaign of unrivaled scale and complexity to outadvertise John McCain nationwide by at least four to one.
articles.abstract: Barack Obama is using an advertising campaign of unrivaled scale and complexity to outadvertise John McCain nationwide by at least four to one.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA  Senator Barack Obama is days away from breaking the advertising spending record set by President Bush in the general election four years ago, having unleashed an advertising campaign of a scale and complexity unrivaled in the television era.

articles.headline: Among Rock-Ribbed Fans of Palin, Dudes Rule
articles.snippet: The stoutest defenders of Sarah Palin, the Republican vice-presidential nominee, are often the Joe Sixpacks in her crowds.
articles.abstract: The stoutest defenders of Sarah Palin, the Republican vice-presidential nominee, are often the Joe Sixpacks in her crowds.
articles.lead_paragraph: BANGOR, Me. — It is not unusual for fans of Sarah Palin to shout out to the Alaska governor in the midst of her stump speeches. It is noteworthy, however, that the crowds are heavily male.

articles.headline: Wary of Islam, China Tightens a Vise of Rules
articles.snippet: China places intricate restrictions on Muslims in a vast autonomous region in an effort to control Islam’s spread.
articles.abstract: China places intricate restrictions on Muslims in a vast autonomous region in an effort to control Islam’s spread.
articles.lead_paragraph: KHOTAN, China  The grand mosque that draws thousands of Muslims each week in this oasis town has all the usual trappings of piety: dusty wool carpets on which to kneel in prayer, a row of turbans and skullcaps for men without headwear, a wall niche facing the holy city of Mecca in the Arabian desert.

articles.headline: Gifts to Pet Charities Keep Lawmakers Happy
articles.snippet: Records of corporate giving to lawmakers’ favorite causes show the extent and lavishness of a once hidden practice.
articles.abstract: Records of corporate giving to lawmakers’ favorite causes show the extent and lavishness of a once hidden practice.
articles.lead_paragraph: They do not seem the most likely classical music patrons: Northrop Grumman, General Dynamics, Boeing and Lockheed Martin.
articles.byline: By Raymond Hernandez and David W. Chen

articles.headline: Building Flawed American Dreams
articles.snippet: For years Henry G. Cisneros helped low-income families buy homes, part of a trend with dire consequences.
articles.abstract: For years Henry G. Cisneros helped low-income families buy homes, part of a trend with dire consequences.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO — A grandson of Mexican immigrants and a former mayor of this town, Henry G. Cisneros has spent years trying to make the dream of homeownership come true for low-income families.
articles.byline: By David Streitfeld and Gretchen Morgenson

articles.headline: Midcareer Rocket Fuel, Courtesy of an Internship
articles.snippet: Across the country, more adult professionals are interested in gaining knowledge through an unpaid or low-paying internship.
articles.abstract: Across the country, more adult professionals are interested in gaining knowledge through an unpaid or low-paying internship.
articles.lead_paragraph: KENWOOD, Calif.

articles.headline: All the Celebrities You Want, on Your Cellphone
articles.snippet: The cellphone has become the latest medium to feed the appetite for up-to-the-second celebrity gossip.
articles.abstract: The cellphone has become the latest medium to feed the appetite for up-to-the-second celebrity gossip.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Kim Kardashian, famous for being famous, sliced her foot on a piece of glass in a New York hotel room in August, the gossip Web site TMZ.com alerted fans over their cellphones. Traffic to the site jumped 10 percent within minutes.

articles.headline: On Wall Street, Eyes Turn to the Fear Index
articles.snippet: The Chicago Board Options Exchange Volatility Index, or the VIX, measures volatility, the technical term for wrenching market swings.
articles.abstract: The Chicago Board Options Exchange Volatility Index, or the VIX, measures volatility, the technical term for wrenching market swings.
articles.lead_paragraph: Fear is running high on Wall Street. Just look at the Fear Index.

articles.headline: Jim Cramer Retreats Along With the Dow
articles.snippet: After years of selling the stock market as a reliable path to riches, CNBC’s star stock-picker has received brutal criticism recently from viewers and competitors.
articles.abstract: After years of selling the stock market as a reliable path to riches, CNBC’s star stock-picker has received brutal criticism recently from viewers and competitors.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last Friday afternoon, Jim Cramer, CNBC’s star stock-picker, took time before taping his hourlong show, “Mad Money,” to talk to a visitor in the cable network’s headquarters in Englewood Cliffs, N.J.

articles.headline: Some Papers in Financial Trouble Are Leaving the A.P. to Cut Costs
articles.snippet: It remains to be seen whether the recent defections become a major problem for the world’s largest news-gathering organization.
articles.abstract: It remains to be seen whether the recent defections become a major problem for the world’s largest news-gathering organization.
articles.lead_paragraph: For most of its 137-year history, The Columbus Dispatch has carried articles and images from The Associated Press. Like most big American newspapers, it supplements the work of its own staff with dozens of items daily from The A.P.

articles.headline: Drug Killings Haunt Mexican Schoolchildren
articles.snippet: Mexico’s explosion of drug-related violence has caught the attention of the country’s children, filling their heads with images that are hard to shake.
articles.abstract: Mexico’s explosion of drug-related violence has caught the attention of the country’s children, filling their heads with images that are hard to shake.
articles.lead_paragraph: TIJUANA, Mexico  The little boy, his school uniform neatly pressed and his friends gathered around, held up 10 little fingers, each one representing a dead body he said he saw outside his school one recent morning. He was not finished, though. He put down the 10 fingers and then put up 2 more. Twelve bodies in all.

articles.headline: Insiders’ Share Sales on Margin on the Rise
articles.snippet: Executives can sometimes appear to own shares in a company, but have actually pledged them as collateral for a loan.
articles.abstract: Executives can sometimes appear to own shares in a company, but have actually pledged them as collateral for a loan.
articles.lead_paragraph: When executives own big stakes in the companies they run, investors can rest a little more easily at night, knowing those managers have the shareholders’ best interests at heart.

articles.headline: Deficit Rises, and Consensus Is to Let It Grow
articles.snippet: Lawmakers have elected to pay for the bailout mainly by borrowing rather than spending cuts or tax hikes.
articles.abstract: Lawmakers have elected to pay for the bailout mainly by borrowing rather than spending cuts or tax hikes.
articles.lead_paragraph: Like water rushing over a river’s banks, the federal government’s rapidly mounting expenses are overwhelming the federal budget and increasing an already swollen deficit.
articles.byline: By Louis Uchitelle and Robert Pear

articles.headline: Many Holes in Disclosure of Nominees’ Health
articles.snippet: The limited information provided by the candidates is a departure from recent, more forthcoming, campaigns.
articles.abstract: The limited information provided by the candidates is a departure from recent, more forthcoming, campaigns.
articles.lead_paragraph: Fifteen days before the election, serious gaps remain in the public’s knowledge about the health of the presidential and vice-presidential nominees. The limited information provided by the candidates is a striking departure from recent campaigns, in which many candidates and their doctors were more forthcoming.

articles.headline: Taking a Peek at the Experts’ Genetic Secrets
articles.snippet: Ten volunteers are putting their genomes online, hoping to aid research.
articles.abstract: Ten volunteers are putting their genomes online, hoping to aid research.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Is Esther Dyson, the technology venture capitalist who is training to be an astronaut, genetically predisposed to a major heart attack?

articles.headline: Donation Record as Colin Powell Endorses Obama
articles.snippet: The endorsement could lift Barack Obama among independents, and his campaign war chest could help him sell that message.
articles.abstract: The endorsement could lift Barack Obama among independents, and his campaign war chest could help him sell that message.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Senator Barack Obama on Sunday captured a forceful endorsement from former Secretary of State Colin L. Powell and announced he had shattered campaign finance records in September, gaining an immense financial edge that will allow him to overwhelm Senator John McCain’s efforts in every corner of the country.

articles.headline: Powell’s Endorsement Puts Spotlight on His Legacy
articles.snippet: Colin L. Powell’s embrace of a Democrat was also an effort to reshape a legacy that he himself considers tainted by his service under President Bush.
articles.abstract: Colin L. Powell’s embrace of a Democrat was also an effort to reshape a legacy that he himself considers tainted by his service under President Bush.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Former Secretary of State Colin L. Powell’s endorsement of Senator Barack Obama on Sunday represented his own transformative moment in a lifelong journey through war and politics.

articles.headline: Signs of Easing Credit and Stimulus Talk Lift Wall Street
articles.snippet: Amid signs that credit was beginning to flow more easily, investors sent the Dow up 413 points. The S.&P. gained 4.8 percent.
articles.abstract: Amid signs that credit was beginning to flow more easily, investors sent the Dow up 413 points. The S.&P. gained 4.8 percent.
articles.lead_paragraph: After weeks of extraordinary efforts by the world’s governments and central banks, the frozen flow of credit began to thaw on Monday.
